author: uncle_irohh
body:
Good work! Only pushback I have is, when a company goes public you will see some misleading insider txns with purchase code P. I like to filter for insider delta own > 0%. 

The alpha might be very different if you looked at cluster buys, filtered for stock px > $10, omitted holding companies etc. 

I also filter for filing delay because if a txn was reported with a 5 day delay, it was not actionable real time for 1-week study.

author: kevinmeatsbacon
body: No real strategy other then looking for areas that have a lot of growth. Research research research. For instance there’s a world wide shortage of semi conductors. Now, I’m not rich so investing in companies like Texas Instruments was out of the picture. HOWEVER, I started looking into companies that supply the materials that MAKE semiconductors and found that the entry level for some of those companies was much more attainable. I’m also the kind of person that prefers long steady growth over massive spiking and dumping.

author: Afro_Superbiker
body: Do you think TXN is still a value play?

author: MonoDun
body: Think of TSMC as Texas Instruments or GE but in semiconductors with razor thin profit margins. Morris Chang actually learnt everything at TI and went back to Taiwan and started it all, kind of a godfather if you will to the whole industry taking off there. TSMC is a stable stock will never go down in value, but we also know the upside unlike say Amazon which keeps finding and gobbling up business anywhere, value unknown could worth $3500 or whatever it is today or it could co down to $15 dollars like it did in 2008. The chip shortage hype will die in a week and TSMC reached its own peak in the last 12 months I think it was $125 to $130, will drop down after the momentum junkies find other hype stocks to play.

author: hyrle
body: QCOM and TXN.  Boring tech stocks that are overlooked by many, not hyped at all - but big producers of semiconductors and other "backbone of the industry" tech products.

author: MeisterTea

author: walkie_0209
body:
ASML's EUV tools cost more than $175mn/machine and new foundries at the scale of what TSMC has been building might cost $20Bn each. 

One could argue that ASML has built a better mousetrap but I don't know of any real competitors for EUV? ASML bought Cymer...  

The real trick would be if ASML found a means to help with implementation of the tools. Intel held back using EUV b/c they didn't want to take the risk. ASML would have done better if Intel was more confident in the roadmap. 

At the same time, single-digit process nodes may not be the only answer. 

The need for analog-to-digital chips only increases: ADI and TXN would be the primary beneficiaries here. 

 Specialists will also benefit: eg, those haptic chips in the Sony PlayStation Controller will be in more and more devices in the future too. 

Networking tends to be a bottleneck ... whoever solves latency problems (Tesla?!) at scale might do very well also

SK is splitting in half ... not sure that's the angle since I believe the dram biz will be part of a larger VC-type business going after themes like the metaverse
